title: Corrections & Amplifications
text:
The name of Hult International Business School was misspelled as Holt International Business School in a Personal Journal article on Monday about workplace etiquette.

(See: "PERSONAL JOURNAL --- Work & Life: Don't Be That Awkward Colleague --- As people go back to offices, they find the rules and boundaries have changed. Here's a guide to the new workplace etiquette." -- WSJ Nov. 8, 2021)

---

Friday's price for nonfat dry milk was 157.00 cents per pound in Chicago. The Cash Prices table in Monday's Business & Finance section incorrectly gave the price as 193.50 cents.

---

Pioneer Natural Resources Co. reported a special variable dividend of $1.51 on Aug. 3. The Dividend Changes table published in Aug. 4's Business & Finance section incorrectly showed an increase in the quarterly base dividend to $1.51 from 56 cents. Also, the company's dividend yield was 1.46% on Aug. 3. The table incorrectly said 3.9%.

---

There are virtually no blue foods in nature; foods such as blueberries and blue corn are more purple in color, according to Charles Spence, a professor of experimental psychology at the University of Oxford. A Journal Report article on Thursday about how restaurants are luring back diners omitted the word virtually.

(See: "Small Business (A Special Report) --- How Restaurants Can Lure Back Customers" -- WSJ Nov. 4, 2021)

---

Notice to readers

Some Wall Street Journal staff members are working remotely during the pandemic. Please send reader comments only by email or phone, using the contacts below, not via U.S. Mail.

---

Readers can alert The Wall Street Journal to any errors in news articles by e-mailing wsjcontact@wsj.com or by calling 888-410-2667.
